newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan hog disease seen under control - officials.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan hog disease seen under control - officials.

text.p: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture said on Thursday an outbreak of foot-and-mouth hog disease had been controlled and domestic pork prices had recovered.

The agriculture council said in a statement all pigs at 5,152 of the 5,840 infected farms had been slaughtered and only 19 new cases were reported on Wednesday, indicating the disease was under control.
The council said more than 3.5 million out of the island's 14 million hogs had been destroyed.
Local wholesale pork prices have recovered from earlier sharp falls and were quoted at T$46 (US$1.67) per kg on Thursday.
Taiwan's wholesale pork prices fell more than 60 percent in the days after the outbreak was announced on March 20.
In southern Taiwan, the average wholesale price of a kilogram of fresh pork was quoted at T$18 (65.4 U.S. cents) just after the outbreak, compared with T$46 (US$1.67) before.
The farm council has issued T$3.58 billion in compensation for slaughtered pigs and T$4.58 billion in loans, the statement said.
Taiwan lifted a pork export ban on April 17.
But pork exporters said no pork exports were expected in the near term because no countries had expressed willingness to accept Taiwanese pork.
